image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

image.altText: Old newspaper articles

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

image.altText: Senior man wearing a shirt receives an injection in his arm.

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: Motorist describes the moment a Sydney petrol station caught fire while he was filling up

image.altText: Anthony Albanese putting on a mask at a press conference.

title.children: Lockdowns and border closures omitted in scope of inquiry into government COVID-19 pandemic response

image.altText: The silhouette of a power station is seen against the sky in the early evening, with thick smoke billowing from three towers.

image.altText: A large lake with vegetarian and logs around the edge.

props.synopsis: A 73-year-old man has been sentenced to two community corrections orders for negligently operating a boat causing the death of two girls near Tamworth late last year.

title.children: Man responsible for deaths of two teens in Lake Keepit boat crash escapes jail time

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

props.synopsis: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes the floor at the UN Security Council to lash 'criminal' Russia before foreign secretary Sergei Lavrov unloads for Russia.

title.children: As Russia ignores Zelenskyy at UN, Ukraine calls for stripping of Russia's veto power

image.altText: A teenage boy and girl, dressed in colourful clothes, walk their bikes as they chat outside school.

props.synopsis: The British sex comedy has portrayed the teenage experience with nuance and humour. Here's everything you need to know before pressing play on the final season.

title.children: The final season of Sex Education has arrived. Here's everything you need to know before saying goodbye

image.altText: Eddie Jones looks pensive after the Wallabies lost to Fiji at the 2023 Rugby World Cup.

props.synopsis: Retired Test winger Drew Mitchell blames veteran coach Eddie Jones for putting the Wallabies in danger of missing the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals for the first time.

image.altText: Image of crowd at music festival at sunset

props.synopsis: Yours and Owls festival organisers want attendees to vote before arriving at the event after a request for on-site voting booths was turned down.

title.children: 20,000 young people will be at this festival on the day of the Voice referendum. But will they vote?

image.altText: Screenshot of Bob Ross with the Walk in the Woods painting during the first episode of his TV series.

props.synopsis: The painting is on sale after spending almost four decades hanging in a TV station volunteer's home.

title.children: First painting from Bob Ross's TV series goes on sale for more than $15m

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

image.altText: Jarome Luai sits on the ground

props.synopsis: Star five-eighth Jarome Luai has been cleared to return from a dislocated shoulder for Penrith's preliminary final against Melbourne.

title.children: Luai cleared to play for Panthers in prelim against Storm

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material

image.altText: Firefighters extinguishing fire in the bush

props.synopsis: The Rural Fire Service says conditions are easing in parts of NSW after more than 100 fires flared over the past three days during heatwave conditions.

title.children: Cool reprieve for NSW after more than 100 fires burned during heatwave

image.altText: The six politicians stand in front of the US Capitol building.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

title.children: Julian Assange unites cross-party delegation in Washington to push for WikiLeaks founder's freedom

image.altText: Writers and supporters holding up signs such as "Writers Guild of America on Strike!" and "It didn't have to be this way"

props.synopsis: Writers and producers could soon reach an agreement to end the writers strike, according to sources, following a meeting with top Hollywood executives.

title.children: 'Positive sign': Hollywood writers talk with studios in hopes of ending strike

image.altText: The silhouette of a firefighter is seen in front of a large bushfire burning high into trees.

props.synopsis: Catastrophic fire danger warnings have been issued in parts of Australia already as it enters a hotter and drier than average climate pattern. If the fire season has taken you by surprise, here's a reminder of how the warning system works.

title.children: What makes a bushfire alert 'catastrophic', and how should you respond?

image.altText: a man in an office with documents

props.synopsis: The ASX sheds 1 per cent in line with global markets after the US central bank stiffens its hawkish stance, while former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX sheds 1pc, former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging, US interest rates unchanged

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Back into the hearing: Speaking about the effect of interest rates on the cost of living, Professor Fels has asked Matthew Lloyd Cape from Per Capita about the proportion of fixed rate mortgages in the UK compared to here. Mr Lloyd Cape said in the UK in 2016 about half of mortgage were fixed, the other half were variable. He continued to say, "Now in the UK about 15 per cent are variable, everyone else is on fixed rates because people were trying to protect themselves during the crisis." Here in Australia Mr Lloyd Cape said about 80 per cent of home loans are variable. He added fixed mortgage rates are lower in the UK, because there are more banks, so more competition. "They have competition driving them to provide something that is a much safer, more effective product for consumers." He was making the point in Per Capita's argument for better competition laws in Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Calls for better competition regulation in Australia

children.content: on the cost of living, Professor Fels has asked
about the proportion of fixed rate mortgages in the UK compared to here.
Mr Lloyd Cape said in the UK in 2016 about half of mortgage were fixed, the other half were variable.
He continued to say, "Now in the UK about 15 per cent are variable, everyone else is on fixed rates because people were trying to protect themselves during the crisis."
Here in Australia Mr Lloyd Cape said about 80 per cent of home loans are variable.
He added fixed mortgage rates are lower in the UK, because there are more banks, so more competition.
"They have competition driving them to provide something that is a much safer, more effective product for consumers."
He was making the point in Per Capita's argument for better competition laws in Australia.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's more to the Chevron dispute on pay and working conditions at the energy giant's two LNG facilities in Western Australia. The Fair Work Commission (FWC) recommended an increase in certain allowances for employees, and said a committee would be set up to work over the next three months to list the skills required for staff to become eligible for promotions. Employees should also be paid to travel to attend training sessions, and Chevron must pay for their flights and accommodation if required, the commission said. Commissioner Bernie Riordan said "I strongly recommend that the parties adopt the recommendations … which will hopefully resolve these disputes." "In my view, the parties are close to achieving their desired outcome of registered enterprise agreements to cover the wages and employment conditions," Riordan said in the filing. "It would be a pity and very frustrating to simply throw out these agreed positions and have the parties return to their respective logs of claims for any future arbitration." Chevron and the unions said they would review the recommendations. The two sides have until 9am AEST on Friday to decide whether to accept the commission's recommendations.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fair Work recommends end to Chevron dispute

children.content: dispute on pay and working conditions at the energy giant's two LNG facilities in Western Australia.

to list the skills required for staff to become eligible for promotions.

of registered enterprise agreements to cover the wages and employment conditions," Riordan said in the filing.

Chevron and the unions said they would review the recommendations.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not just our market that's fallen today. Japan's Nikkei is also more than 1 per cent lower. Technology heavyweights tracked their US peers lower after the Federal Reserve stiffened its hawkish stance with a further interest rate hike projected by the end of the year. The Nikkei had fallen 1.14 per cent to 32,647.72 by the midday break. Chip-testing equipment maker Advantest the biggest drag, shedding 2.34 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Japanese Nikkei also down 1pc

children.content: It's not just our market that's fallen today.
Technology heavyweights tracked their US peers lower after the Federal Reserve stiffened its hawkish stance with a further interest rate hike projected by the end of the year.

image.altText: Elon Musks' face is pictured behind the logo for Neuralink.

props.synopsis: Elon Musk's brain-chip startup Neuralink says it will begin recruiting for the first human trial of its brain implant for paralysis patients after receiving approval from an independent review board.

props.synopsis: As debate over the Voice continues around the country, locals in this remote South Australian community are focused on issues closer to home.
